raw_text:
US industrial output growth eases
 
 US industrial production continued to rise in November, albeit at a slower pace than the previous month.
 
 The US Federal Reserve said output from factories, mines and utilities rose 0.3% - in line with forecasts - from a revised 0.6% increase in October. Analysts added that if the carmaking sector - which saw production fall 0.5% - had been excluded the data would have been more impressive. The latest increase means industrial output has grown 4.2% in the past year. Many analysts were upbeat about the prospects for the US economy, with the increase in production coming on the heels of news of a recovery in retail sales. "This is very consistent with an economy growing at 3.5 to 4.0%. It is congruent with job growth and consumer optimism," Comerica chief economist David Littman said of the figures.
 
 The US economy grew at a respectable annual rate of 3.7% in the three months between July and September, while jobs growth averaged 178,000 during the same period. While the employment figures are not spectacular, experts believe they are enough to whittle away at America's 5.4% jobless rate. A breakdown of the latest production figures shows mining output drove the increase, surging 2.1%, while factory output rose 0.3%. But utility output dropped 1.4%. Meanwhile, the amount of factory capacity in use during the month rose to 77.6% - its highest level since May 2001. "Many investors think that product market inflation won't be a problem until the utilisation rates are at 80% or higher," Cary Leahy, senior US economist at Deutsche Bank Securities, said. "So there is still a lot of inflation-fighting slack in the manufacturing sector," "Overall I'd say manufacturing at least away from autos continues to improve and I would bet that it improves at a faster rate in coming months given how lean inventories are," Citigroup senior economist Steven Wieting added.
llama3.2:1b: US industrial production increased 0.3% in November, rising from a revised 0.6% increase in October.
This is the fourth month of growth in US industrial output, with an annual growth rate of 4.2%.
The data is consistent with an economy growing at 3.5-4.0%, and experts believe it will lead to job growth and consumer optimism.
llama3.2:3b: US industrial production rose 0.3% in November, with mining output surging 2.1%.
The annual growth rate is 4.2%, and many analysts believe the US economy is growing at a rate of 3.5-4.0%.
Factory capacity utilization reached its highest level since May 2001, at 77.6%.
gemma2:2b: US industrial production increased 0.3% in November, after a 0.6% increase in October.
The increase was driven by mining output, which rose 2.1%, and factory output, which rose 0.3%.
While the overall growth rate is strong, some analysts note that excluding car production shows a more impressive result.
The US economy grew at 3.7% in the third quarter of 2023.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US industrial output growth eases, data shows growth of 4.2% in the past year compared to 3.7% three months earlier.
Mining and utility sectors showed positive growth while factories saw a decrease in output.
This is consistent with an economy growing at 3.5-4%, job growth, and consumer optimism.
Manufacturing continues to improve but there are still inflation concerns due to lean inventories.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US industrial output growth slowed compared to October, with factories and utilities seeing modest increases but the automotive sector shrinking by 0.5%.
Despite some slowdowns, overall production remains strong, with a year-over-year increase of 4.2% and expectations for continued positive economic indicators due to recent retail sales recovery.
qwen2.5:3b: US industrial production grew 0.3% in November, aligning with forecasts but below the 0.6% increase in October.
Excluding car manufacturing, which fell by 0.5%, the growth would have been stronger.
Over the past year, it has grown 4.2%.
The economy is expected to grow at a rate of 3.5-4.0% annually.
Mining output drove up overall production with a 2.1% rise and factory output increased by 0.3%, while utility output decreased by 1.4%.
Factory capacity utilization reached its highest level since May 2001 at 77.6%.
Analysts predict manufacturing improvement will continue, especially given the low inventory levels.
opencoder:1.5b: The US industrial production continued to rise in November, albeit at a slower pace than the previous month.
The US Federal Reserve said output from factories, mines and utilities rose 0.3% - in line with forecasts - from a revised 0.6% increase in October.
Analysts added that if the carmaking sector had been excluded the data would have been more impressive.
The latest increase means industrial output has grown 4.2% in the past year.
While the employment figures are not spectacular, experts believe they are enough to whittle away at America's 5.4% jobless rate.
smollm:1.7b: The US industrial output growth eases, which means the production of goods and services by factories, mines, and utilities increased slightly from its previous month.
The increase is consistent with forecasts, as it indicates a growing economy.
The employment figures are also positive, which suggests that the number of people working in the US has increased.
The US economy grew at a respectable annual rate of 3.7% between July and September, while jobs growth averaged 178,000 during the same period.
While the employment figures are not spectacular, they are enough to whittle away at America's 5.4% jobless rate.
A breakdown of the latest production figures shows that mining output rose 2.1%, while factory output increased 0.3%.
The amount of factory capacity in use during the month rose to 77.6% - its highest level since May 2001 - which suggests that there is still some inflation-fighting slack in the manufacturing sector.
Overall, I'd say that the US industrial production growth eases are positive signs for the economy and would be a good sign for the coming months.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: US industrial production continued to rise in November, slightly slower than October, with a 0.3% increase matching forecasts.
Analysts noted excluding the carmaking sector might have enhanced the data's impressive growth, yet the rise indicates robust economic momentum.
The year-over-year growth reached 4.2%, with industry employment averaging 178,000 and jobless rates at 5.4%.
Mining output surged 2.1%, while utilities dropped 1.4%, though capacity utilization peaked at 77.6%.
Experts caution about inflation risks but highlight manufacturing's improving outlook, with inventories showing slack to improve further in the future.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US industrial production grew by 0.3% compared to the previous month, according to data released by the Federal Reserve on November 29.
This is an impressive increase and comes on the heels of a strong report in retail sales.
Analysts were upbeat about the prospects for the US economy, with industrial production contributing positively to the overall growth figure.
The rise in production came despite a drop in utility output, which has been seen as an indication of product market inflation.

However, experts believe that product market inflation won't be a problem until the utilities' utilization rates reach 80%, with investors thinking that demand for products will outstrip supply before such rates can be reached.

The latest report from the Federal Reserve may help to clarify any concerns about product market inflation, and economists are expecting manufacturing in the US to improve at a faster rate in coming months.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Industrial production increased by 0.3% in November, according to data released by the US Federal Reserve on Monday.
The increase follows an increase of 0.6% in October and means industrial output has grown by a total of 4.2% during the past year.
This positive performance in manufacturing is particularly impressive considering that many analysts expected a decrease in production, according to data from retail sales.
The US economy is growing at a respectable annual rate of 3.5 to 4.0%, and job growth has averaged 178,000 during the same period.
Despite the positive economic trends, experts believe that a decline in utilisation rates among factories is still a concern.
Cary Leahy, Deutsche Bank Securities senior US economist, mentioned that many investors think that product market inflation won't be a problem until utilisation rates are at 80%.
However, there is still a lot of slack in the manufacturing sector and it continues to improve.
Overall, I would say manufacturing has improved and bets on an improvement in utilisation rates suggest that it improves faster as well, according to Citigroup senior economist Steven Wieting.
phi:2.7b: Industrial output in November increased 0.3%, following a rise of 0.6% in October.
The carmaking sector, which saw production fall by 0.5%, was excluded from the data.
Despite this, many analysts remain optimistic about the US economy, as the increase in production coincides with recovery in retail sales and job growth averaging 178,000 per month.
The 3.7% annual GDP growth rate for July-September is consistent with a growing economy, according to Comerica's chief economist David Littman.
Mining output surged by 2.1%, while factory output rose 0.3%.
The amount of capacity in use during the month was at its highest since May 2001.
The US unemployment rate is decreasing due to job growth, averaging 178,000 per month.
While the employment figures are not outstanding, experts believe they will continue to decrease gradually.
Manufacturing has improved over time, and inventory levels remain low, according to Citigroup's senior economist Steven Wieting.
orca-mini:3b: US industrial output growth eased in November, with the Federal Reserve stating that production rose 0.3% from a revised 0.6% increase in October.
Output excluding the carmaking sector was more impressive if removed.
The US economy grew at a 3.7% annual rate in the three months between July and September, while job growth averaged 178,000 during the same period.
A breakdown of the latest production figures shows mining output driving the increase, while factory output rose 0.3%.
The utilisation rate of factory capacity in use during the month increased to 77.6% - its highest level since May 2001.
Many investors think product market inflation won't be a problem until utilisation rates are at 80% or higher, and there is still slack in the manufacturing sector.
Overall, I'd say manufacturing continues to improve and I would bet that it improves faster in coming months given how lean inventories are.
hermes3:3b: US industrial production increased 0.3% in November, slightly slower than previous month, 4.2% up year-on.
Jobless rate may be whittled down with steady job growth (178k avg between July-Sept).
stablelm-zephyr:3b: US industrial production growth eased in November, with an increase of 0.3% in line with forecasts, although analysts noted the data would have been more impressive if the carmaking sector hadn't been excluded.
Industrial output has grown 4.2% over the past year, and many experts are optimistic about the US economy's prospects, particularly given a recovery in retail sales.
Mining output drove the increase, while factory output rose 0.3% and utility output dropped 1.4%.
chatgpt-4o-latest: US industrial production rose 0.3% in November, slowing from October’s 0.6% increase.
Excluding a 0.5% decline in car production, the data would have been stronger.
Over the past year, industrial output grew 4.2%.
Analysts remain optimistic about the economy, citing job growth and consumer confidence.
The US economy expanded at an annual rate of 3.7% from July to September, with job growth averaging 178,000, helping reduce the 5.4% unemployment rate.
Mining output surged 2.1%, factory output rose 0.3%, while utility output fell 1.4%.
Factory capacity utilization reached 77.6%, the highest since May 2001, with analysts suggesting inflation concerns remain low.
Experts predict further manufacturing growth, particularly outside the auto sector, due to lean inventories.
stablelm2:1.6b: US industrial output grew by 0.3% in November, despite a slower pace compared to October.
Excluding the car manufacturing sector, which saw a 0.5% decrease, the growth rate would have been more impressive at 4.2%.
Analysts predict that without the car industry's impact, US economic growth is consistent with an annual rate of 3.5-4.0%.
Mining output led the increase, while factory and utility outputs rose.
The utilisation rates in manufacturing also improved, reaching its highest level since May at 6.6%.
Experts believe utilisation rates will reach a higher threshold before product market inflation becomes a problem.
granite3.1-dense:2b: US industrial output growth moderated slightly in November, rising 0.3% compared to the previous month, according to the Federal Reserve.
This figure, aligned with forecasts, represents a decline from October's revised 0.6%.
Excluding the automotive sector, which saw production fall 0.5%, industrial output growth would have been more robust.
Over the past year, industrial output has increased by 4.2%.
Analysts maintain optimism about the US economy due to this production uptick and a recent retail sales rebound.
Comerica's chief economist, David Littman, noted that the growth aligns with an annual rate of 3.5 to 4.0% economic expansion, consistent with job growth and consumer confidence.
The US economy expanded at an annual rate of 3.7% from July to September, while job creation averaged 178,000 during the same period.
Although not exceptional, these figures are expected to help decrease the unemployment rate from its current 5.4%.
Mining output led the increase with a rise of 2.1%, followed by a 0.3% gain in factory production.
The utilization rate of manufacturing capacity reached 77.6%, its highest level since May 2001.

Deutsche Bank Securities' Cary Leahy and Citigroup's Steven Wieting anticipate further improvement in industrial output, especially as inventories are lean, and inflation-fighting slack is diminishing.
